course.subject: PHYS
course.name: Introduction to Astrophysics and Astronomy
course.description: This course introduces students to origin of modern astronomy, gravity, light and telescope, star light and atoms, stars (binary, formation, evolution, death), neutron stars and black holes, normal galaxies, peculiar galaxies, cosmology, the solar system, life on other world. Students without the physics prerequisite but have taken CORE 1110 or equivalent may seek instructor’s approval for enrolling in the course.
course.prerequisites: Level 3 or above in HKDSE 1/2x OR in HKDSE 1x Physics

reviews.author: Saber Athena
reviews.title: 從何時開始怕遙望星塵
reviews.comment_content:
=Average Common Core with Average Grading=

Chapter 1 A Modern View of the Universe
Chapter 2 Discovering the Universe for Yourself
Chapter 3 The Science of Astronomy
Chapter 4 Making Sense of the Universe: Understanding Motion, Energy, and Gravity
Chapter 5-6 Light and Matter: Reading messages from the Cosmos; Telescopes: Portals of Discovery
Chapter 14 Our Star
Chapter 15 Surveying the Stars
Chapter 16-17 Star Birth and Star Stuff
Chapter 18 The Bizarre Stellar Graveyard
Chapter 19 Our Galaxy
Chapter 20-21 Galaxies and the Foundation of Modern Cosmology; Galaxy Evolution
Chapter 22-23 The Birth of the Universe; Dark Matter, Dark Energy, and the Fate of the Universe

=Prerequisite=
  The course requires you to know the formulas, and when and how to use the formulas. It is very similar to what they do in HKDSE physics, or physics 1112. Theoretically, you will be able to get the questions right even without a physics background (If you are very smart). More on that in the Grading part.

=Content=
  Trust me, they are not as interesting as they sound.

  The course started with plenty of memorization of not-so interesting concepts. Those includes the concept of light-year, look-back time etc, which are essentially complex ways of describing really far objects. And then we moved on to talking about the phases of the moon and the formation of seasons, which is all about imagining how a big sphere (also known as the Moon) rotates around a even bigger sphere (also known as the Earth). If you are good at imagination, you are gonna have a good time.

  After the Mid-term we moved onto more interesting topics like supernovas and black holes. But then the professor decided to rush the topics which made these interesting topics not so interesting.

  As expected, which more interesting topics came more complex calculations. At some point, a Greek astronomer Hipparchus decided that measuring distance is idiotic and decided to implement a more idiotic way of measuring distance, known as "apparent magnitude" and "the M&M equation". If you are not super good at Physics, you are going to have a very bad time in dealing with those.

=Textbook=
  Buy the textbook. I didn't buy the textbook. I strongly recommend buying the textbook.
  The lecture notes are in point form and contain mistakes here and there.  Some lecture slides don't even have words. Using the lecture notes alone will NOT help you to understand the concept. The textbook provides more in depth explaining, plus some exercises for you to do.

  P.S: Nevertheless, The lecture PowerPoint covers everything there is in the exam. Using the PPTs are adequate for you to answer all of the questions in the Exam. If you don't really care about what you are learning (Like me), then you don't have to buy the textbook.

  P.P.S: I was almost the only girl in the whole class. Please don't reg this course if you can't stand boy-only environment)
reviews.comment_teaching:
=CHEN Tian Wen=
  I can't really comment about his look. Through the Zoom video I could't see much other than his forehead and his hair. (He does have pretty good hair).
  He did tried his best to make in-class interactions (In the first few lessons at least). After while he probably realized that no one really pays attention in Zoom-lectures and gave up entirely.
  He seems to be a pretty nice guy and I'm sure that he's willing to answer your question if you have any. But he did a really bad job explaining concepts. (Probably something to do with his flat tones making it hard to focus).
  Takes attendance through iPRS in class, which will take up 5% of your exam grade. The iPRS questions are really EASY! You will be able to get them right if you have paid any attention in class. (btw I got half of them wrong)
  His English is alright.

=Michael Altman=
  Some point in the semester I got fed up with Chen Tian Wen's teaching style and I decided to sit in Altman's lesson. He doesn't seem to be that much different from Chen. Gave up after 1 lesson, went back to Chen's class.
reviews.comment_grading:
=Midterm=
  Midterm is scary. Midterm is split into two parts, the MC (In total 20) and the Long Questions (In total 2)
  Perhaps because of the online Exam mode this semester, the Exam got really difficult and calculation involved. Almost all questions requires some level of comprehension and calculations.
  The past paper released before hand are really easy. So I was kinda caught off-guard in the actual mid-term. I didn't have enough time to finish the last questions. I also didn't make my own notes for the midterm, so I wasted most time frantically going through the lecture notes. Bad idea.

=Finals=
  The format and difficulties of the final exam are very similar to the mid-term. (Also three times longer). Some people say it's harder than the mid-term but I don't really think so. The last part of the Final, very much like the last part of the MT, contains very complex questions with a relatively short time limit.
  I was much better prepared for the finals. I've made my own notes and formula sheet, so I was able to answer the questions very quickly. But still, I find a lot of the calculation questions difficult. For the last part (calculation questions), I only finished half because 1) I don't know how to do the rest and 2) I don't have time to do the rest.

=iPRS=
  That 5% is not worth waking up 9AM everyday.

Grades:
Midterm: 70.5/86
Finals: 85/100
Final Grade: A+
Good Enough.
Statistics Attached for your reference. (For reference: DSE PHY 5*, No astronomy component)
reviews.comment_workload:
=Good News=
No Homework. (Yay)

=Bad News=
  The Exams are hell.

  The contents might seem easy, with both exams being open-book. But most of the questions involve understanding and calculations, which really test your understanding and the time you've spent on the topic.

  Study the lecture notes thoroughly, if you have time, make your own notes. Don't rely on going through the notes in the actual exam. There is no way that is gonna work.

  My advise would be treating this subject as a serious Physics course. Study it the way your would study for PHYS1112 or MATH1014. Understand all of the equations, do as much exercise as you can.

  The workload will not be extremely light. But compare this to other 3-credit courses like 1014 or 1112, then you have an  easy (relatively) good-grade common core.  

-Saber Athena

reviews.author: rind
reviews.title: 對天文有興趣嘅好推薦讀
reviews.comment_content:
如果你本身係天文發燒友，又唔想掂咁多physics野，咁呢科都幾啱讀。
Midterm前會講地球嘅野，例如日蝕月蝕，潮漲退，四季，星座果啲，由於呢啲野係日常生活可以接觸到或者係聽得多，所以都幾易學同埋幾有用。
Midterm後就係講宇宙啲野，由近到遠，太陽系、clusters, galaxies, stars formation, black holes...亦都包左好多難嘅野係最後兩個lecture, dark energy, dark matter, Big Bang theory. 基本上聽唔明係正常嘅，佢考你嘅野都只會係notes入面有嘅野，唔洗太擔心，當係比個觀念大家或者比大家有個知字。
reviews.comment_teaching:
我呢個sem reg左Altman嘅lecture，因為係陳天問係9點堂。
Altman堂我好少上，我諗佢都教得ok嘅，但可能個tone比較單一，我覺得有啲難集中。
因為今個sem online teaching，所以兩個lecture嘅lecture video都有send出黎，因為我phys1112上開陳天問堂，所以我溫書都係煲返佢啲片。
陳天問可以話係人如其名，天問呢個名其實係來自屈原嘅一首長詩，講嘅係天文相關嘅野，配合埋呢個course真係啱啱好。同埋佢上堂都好搞笑，講到月亮嘅時候自己係度背水調歌頭，啲ppt又成日加幾首詩入去，搞到Altman教果陣唔知咩黎。
陳天問教書都好清𥇦，因為佢係local prof所以佢啲口音好易明，同埋就係佢教concept果陣會raise一啲問題出黎先教，啲野感覺無咁鬆散，但呢科去到Midterm後啲野比較informative，所以佢都係照讀ppt，好建議Midterm前上佢果啲lecture。
同埋陳天問個lecture啲iprs好似簡單啲。

reviews.comment_content:
由地球天文地理講起，mid-term前會講恒星、gravity、tidal force、星座，會學Kepler's laws of planetary motion，所有會有數計。

Mid-term後會講太陽系、恒星誕生衰亡、黑洞、星雲、星團、星系、類星體⋯⋯

最後幾堂會講啲更複雜嘅嘢，例如暗物質、暗能量、大爆炸、宇宙形狀，呢部份都係理論，聽唔明唔係大問題，可以當故事咁聽。

reviews.author: Undecided
reviews.comment_content:
To be honest, not too much breadth/depth, targeted to people without too much physics background. The quantitative components are intuitive given a decent physics background. I took IB physics HL, but not the astronomy option, so others' experience may differ.

Course Outline:

PART I: Developing Perspective
Chapter 1: A Modern View of the Universe
Chapter 2: Discovering the Universe for Yourself
Chapter 3: The Science of Astronomy

PART II: Key Concepts for Astronomy
Chapter 4: Making Sense of the Universe: Understanding Motion, Energy, and Gravity
Chapter 5-6: Light and Matter: Reading messages from the Cosmos; Telescopes: Portals of Discovery

PART III: Stars
Chapter 14: Our Star
Chapter 15: Surveying the Stars
Chapter 16-17: Star Birth and Star Stuff
Chapter 18: The Bizarre Stellar Graveyard

PART IV: Galaxies and Beyond
Chapter 19: Our Galaxy
Chapter 20-21: Galaxies and the Foundation of Modern Cosmology; Galaxy Evolution
Chapter 22-23: The Birth of the Universe;Dark Matter, Dark Energy, and the Fate of the Universe
reviews.comment_teaching: The pacing of lectures can be quite slow, with iPRS usually at the end of each lecture. If confident/lazy, you can arrive in the last 15-20 minutes and just scroll through the PowerPoint at your own pace. Even if you don't get the materials in the lecture, most iPRS questions are easily Googleable within the 120 seconds given anyways.
reviews.comment_grading:
The difficulty/quantity of content covered by the midterms and finals are similar, even though the final is weighed more, so factor this into the study plan. There are more qualitative facts/tidbits to remember for the final through.

Midterm (38%): MCQs and Problems
Final (57%): MCQs and Problems (changed to MCQ only for the online test)
iPRS (5%): MCQ, best 80%, half mark for incorrect answers, none for MIA

My grade:
Midterm: ~90%
Final: ~90%
iPRS: ~75%
Overall: ~90% → A+
reviews.comment_workload: Not much. Optional worksheets, iPRS every lecture. Most of the workload is the pre-exam crunch to write and collate the notes/cheatsheet. This is 2 sides A4 for the midterm, and 4 sides for the final. Just going through the powerpoints to jot down key points/formulae, this would take around of 6 hours minimum for each exam.

reviews.author: jacky.k.p
reviews.title: Hard course with fair grading
reviews.comment_content:
At the start of the semester, things are simple to follow and most students will be able to catch up the progress of the lectures, which fits the role of an introduction course.
However, getting close to mid-term and afterwards, the difficulty of the course is suddenly raised with the rate of information inflow increasing as well, making lectures hard to follow.
As the course title suggests, this courses is a combination of theories and calculation, content about the universe, from solar system to black-holes and the history of the universe.
reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching is fair, mostly reading out PowerPoints, but quite many animations and videos are played during lectures. Professors and TAs are open to question after the lectures. There are also special sessions for raising questions before mid-term and final exam.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading consists of 3 parts:
1. iPRS (1 per lecture)
2. Mid-term (2-page A4 cheat-sheets allowed)
3. Final exam (4-page A4 cheat-sheets allowed, does not include things in Mid-term)

Lectures do not count attendance, you can ask friends for help in iPRS so lectures can be skipped. Mid-term and final exam both consists mostly MC questions and 3-4 long questions. Calculation is required for a fair amount but mostly substituting into equations, so understanding of the usage of different equations is way more important.

The cheat-sheets are enough to squeeze everything thing in the lecture notes in, but solely relying on cheat-sheets will not be enough for getting good grades.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is zero.
Exercise is given through canvas but you do not need to hand in.
Just try not to miss any of the iPRS questions.

reviews.author: bp
reviews.title: Interesting course with good grade. Recommended.
reviews.comment_content: This course mainly focuses on preliminary knowledge of astronomy. It covers methods of measuring astronomical parameter, types of astronomical bodies and their life cycles explained, and eventually a touch on cosmology. I would say the course teaching is quite deep, but it can explain things clearly. It will teach you the somehow complex HR diagram, and even some fancy stuffs like dark matter and dark energy, but you will find everything seems to make sense. Nevertheless, students without Physics background may find it challenging.
reviews.comment_teaching: Dr. Chen is a gentleman. He will answer your questions in details and not make you doubtful. His English is acceptable. he will sometimes mention useful facts in lessons, but most of the time I have fallen asleep.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is excellent in my opinion. 30% midterm, 65% final exam and 5% PRS. I got full marks in midterm and PRS, and 170/180 in final. A+ at last.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is very light. No hw and reading materials. Only attend lessons or just finish PRS is enough.
Dr. Chen will give 5-6 minutes for a PRS question. Relax and enjoy.

reviews.author: Hyunjun
reviews.comment_content:
It's pretty interesting to broaden your cosmological understanding. If you get it, it's fun; if not, it's boring.
Lecture slides are simply pasted texts that I read the first few sentences interestingly and lose focus and have to read them repeatedly.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Good if you are local, bad if international.

Too much Hong Kong accent that I couldn't understand anything.  What I did was download all the lecture slides, read it first, find some youtube videos that deals with the same topic, and get back to the slides.

reviews.author: tom11144
reviews.title: A non-physics physics course
reviews.comment_content:
Extremely boring, sleep in class.
The content is quite abstract, who else can explain physics without mathematics? For the first part( celestial sphere, moon orbit ....) you better build a model in your head to prepare for the exam and you can get good grade, but for the second part( stars, sun, supernova etc), all of them are extremely vague(like air). If you want to study sth solid, then don't register this course. To be honest, the content of phys 1112 makes more sense then phys 1002, this course is just suitable for students who are good at memorising meaningless stuff.
reviews.comment_teaching:
No comment, I fell asleep in class usually.
for the iprs compared to prof.chen, it is quite difficult, recommend you to go to prof.chen class.

Not that decent.
midterm: 94/100
upper quartile is 94 cuz the exam is too easy for everyone.
final: 80/100
upper quartile is 77.5
grade: A-

didn't pay attention in class after midterm, spent 3 days to study, so damn tough :(
reviews.comment_workload:
objectively, it is low ( iprs )
subjectively, the material is extremely abstract, so it is huge.

reviews.author: desmond fanboy
reviews.title: Not bad
reviews.comment_content:
Refer to others for details.

A basic intro course to astronomy with only a little bit of mathematics involved.

The content after the mid-terms get much more interesting, as it covers topics like star formations, black holes, cosmic radiation, and the fate of the universe.

But if you don't like memorizing 400+ slides for the final exam, and prefer a more mathematical-approach, reconsider taking this course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Chen tries his best to teach and his accent is understandable, but the lectures can get quite boring at times.

Decent teaching overall.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading scheme is as follows:

Midterm 38%
Final 57%
iPRS 5%

Professor Chen's grading bu cuo.

I got 0.8 sd above mean for both mid term and final, and still ended up with an A-.

If you are good at rote memorization, you would probably earn at least a B+.
reviews.comment_workload: Literally no workload at all. Just try to memorize every detail in the lecture slides and you should be good.

reviews.author: NelsonLhxs
reviews.title: DON'T GO IF YOU ARE NOT A GENIUS
reviews.comment_content: Same as others mentioned below. As a learner , I don't find what I have learned is very useful. So, if you just want a good grade, find other courses
reviews.comment_teaching:
Not quite good..... The lesson before midterm makes me feel asleep.  It starts to be interesting after the midterm, but also very confusing....

In short words, the prof only knows how to read ppt and play some flash demo
reviews.comment_grading:
Grade:B
I got 80/100 in midterm with a mean of 83.1....
I get to speak with it..., I won't attend this class if I know these marks before, What a terrible distribution of marks!!!! , 30% of students get 90 or above, and that is why the mean is so high...

I got 74.5 in the final with a mean at 75.1
Most of the people got marks with in 80~90...

IPRS is also counted into the marks , about 5%
reviews.comment_workload:
no workload at all, but there is a cheat sheet that you need to write before the test.
And my suggestion is to WRITE ANY THINGS YOU CAN IN THE PAPER AS NO MATTER HOW IRRELEVANT OF THE CONTENT IS, IT SEEM TO BE LIKELY TO SHOW UP IN THE TEST

reviews.author: michaelleung
reviews.comment_content: Good and deep content, not too rough and can maintain the interest, have a lot of topics ranging from dse elective level to advanced levels. Not very related to classical physics, but still fun
reviews.comment_teaching: A little bit boring, yet there are videos and stuff and models. Attending lectures allow a lot of question time, can ask a lot.
reviews.comment_grading: Got a- even when only studying for 2 days. But my exam allows bringing cheat sheet, and so it will be better to remember the graphs and equations if you want good grade.
reviews.comment_workload: no workload

reviews.author: Hwoakley
reviews.comment_content: Quite nice. Most of the content would have been covered in the last years of school physics e.g. photoelectric effect, Kepler's Laws and laws of gravitation.
reviews.comment_teaching: Good. No issues with any of the topics. There's always time to speak to the TA or professor at the end of the lecture if you need help.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm and final exams are both multiple choice with computational and content based questions. We could use a cheat sheet that is two sides of A4 for the midterm and four sides for the final.

Grading:
Attendance/midterm/final
10/45/45
reviews.comment_workload: Very Easy. Midterm, final and iPRS (end of every lecture to check attendance).

reviews.author: hardplastic
reviews.comment_content:
This course is recommended to those who are interested in astronomy. The content is very much organized. It basically covers all aspects of astronomy in an introductory level, starting from the history and developement of astronomy, to some stellar astrophysics like stellar evolution, and eventually to cosmology, which includes fancy things like dark matter, expansion of the Universe etc. and the detailed course outline can be found in other reviews.

The content largely overlaps with DSE physics astronomy elective, so people who have studied astronomy before has a huge advantage in this course.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Sou's teaching is quite good, it is just his tone is too flat and some of his pronouciation is quite weird, for example he reads 'person' as 'persian'. But overall, it is still fine and acceptable.
reviews.comment_grading:
IPRS is used to take attendence, it contributes 5% to your total score, you get 0, 0.5, 1 for evey unattempt, incorret, correct IPRS respectively. So, if you think you don't need this 5%, you can skip all the lessons.

Our midterm is very eazy, the mean is 83.1/100
The final is a little bit more difficult, the mean is 75.1/100

Grading Scheme:
Midterm: 37%
Final: 58%
iPRS: 5%

My score:
Midtrem: 100/100, highest 100/100
Final: 92.5/100, highest 97/100
IPRS: 5/5
Overall: 95.65%
Final grade: A+
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is extremely small. Homework is optional, only things to do is IPRS and the exams.

reviews.comment_content:

This course basically covered most of the general knowledge about the universe and astronomy, some part of the content require numerical calculation and some understanding of physics. If you can handle mathematics or physics well in high school, this course shouldn't be much of a problem to study.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Chen has rich knowledge in terms of course content and is willing to answer questions from student in class or through other means

In Zoom class, Prof. Chen can explain course content in detail, but not very interesting.
reviews.comment_grading:
Assessment
x% by Homework
y% by Midterm Exam
45% by Final Exam
15% by iPRS

The assessment scheme is quite complicated this semester, the weighting of the hw and midterm are determined by student themselves (each students can have their own weighting).

I got a course overall score of 71/100 and ended up with B+, with the mean score in my class of around 65/100
reviews.comment_workload:
In every class (online mode), there will be a in class mc question (iprs) for you to take to earn point, so basically you will want to attend class to take the quiz. The question can sometimes be challenging, depending on the topic.

Every week, there will be an online homework to take which includes 10 mc questions related to the previously taught content, about half of them are numerical question. In some questions you can get the answer by online searching, but sometimes the question may not be specific and is hard to search for answer, so that you may need to spend time on lecture notes to look for answer, in my opinion, the lecture note that they gave is not well organized

The difficulty of midterm and final (all MCs) are considered moderate in my opinion, you can handle the question alright if you studied the past paper that they gave well enough, but it is just a bit of too much content to memorize when it comes to the final exam in my opinion

reviews.author: Testing1234
reviews.comment_content: Same as previous years. I think the content can be shorter since we don't have time to cover all of them deeply during the lectures. Professor Chen has to speedrun the last few chapters since we have no time to cover them. There is also an extra lecture due to the tight schedule.
reviews.comment_teaching: I think professor Chen is trying his best to build a connection with us. But it is nearly impossible through Zoom. Noone is turning on their camera and giving any response. Basically, professor Chen is reading the PowerPoint directly with some add-on information. To me it is acceptable since I can understand what's happening.
reviews.comment_grading:
There are 4 grading schemes IN THIS SEMESTER.

PRS 15%
HW: 10 Canvas Online Quizzes (MC, difficulty similar to past papers)
Midterm: Postponed to April
Final Exam 45%

Score A = 15% PRS + x% HW + y% Midterm + 45% Final
Score B = 15% PRS + x% HW + (45 + y)% Final
Score C = 15% PRS + y% Midterm + (45 + x)% Final
Score D = 15% PRS + 85% Final
x + y = 40
Overall Score = Max(A, B, C, D)

For me, score A is chosen. I chose 0% midterm 40% homework.

IPRS: 14/15 (93%)
Midterm: skipped
Homework: 64/80 (80%)
Final: 34/49 (69%)
Overall score: 76/100 (mean:65.56)
Grade: A-
reviews.comment_workload: The only workload will be the homework if you chose to do it. 10 MC questions per weekend. You will have around 2 days to complete them.

reviews.author: LIFEGOOD
reviews.title: Good and interesting Common Core Subject
reviews.comment_content:
Same as previous years.

I am not a gifted person in physics and math, but I do believe I work very hard. If you are someone who puts decent amount of effort for this course, you will not have any problem in understanding the course material. Although it is a PHYSICS course in UST, it is one of the easy ones to understand I guess (I am an engineering major).  However, there is many contents to remember instead of understanding.

Personally, second half of the contents are more interesting to me, as we learn about dark matter, big bang theory, and black holes. Some calculations are involved, but they are very straight forward (high school level). If you did well in physics during high school, you will not have a problem.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Chen's teaching is very good. At first, as I never learned about astrophysics some of the contents are very new to me. But when I watched the lecture recording the second time and read the lecture slides carefully, everything was easy to understand. He replies my email very quickly. He even gave me some hints  when I asked him about some HW questions. He speaks a very good English, so if you are an international student (like me), you will not have any problem in understanding. I cannot comment on TAs as I never interacted with them, but they were professionals during exam times.
reviews.comment_grading:
Assessment Format
x% by Homework Online MC Quizzes
y% by Midterm Exam Multiple Choice, Online
45% by Final Exam Multiple Choice, Online
15% by iPRS Answering questions by iPRS in lectures
Score A = 15% PRS + x% HW + y% Midterm + 45% Final
Score B = 15% PRS + x% HW + (45 y )% Final
Score C = 15% PRS + y% Midterm + (45 + x)% Final
Score D = 15% PRS + 85% Final
x + y = 40
Overall Score = Max(A, B, C, D)

Your grade will be calculated by all 4 grading schemes and the best one will be recorded for your final letter grade.

I did quite well in HW and finals, and I chose not to do on midterms. Professor also released the overall score on canvas after final exam, as well as final letter grade. So I could know the letter grade before it was updated on USThing

There are 8 HWs, each with 10 MCQ questions. The difficulty of HW questions are the same as the past year papers, and I found them quite tricky. I would say it is hard to get full marks, but getting above mean is not difficult.

Class mean:
iPRS : idk sorry, but i guess at least 0.6/1
HW overall : 6.4/10
Midterm : I skipped, so idk sorry :)
Final exam : 24.6/50
Overall mean score : 65.6/100

My grade:
iPRS :  I only got wrong in 4 questions
HW overall : 7.6/10
Midterm exam : skipped
Final exam : 36/50
Overall score : 75/100
Final Letter Grade : A-

My grade was the best when using 'Score A'

A- for overall score of 75%. Not bad in UST's harsh grading scheme I guess. I skipped Midterm, and only study 5 days before the final exam. Very good course with very good grading indeed
reviews.comment_workload: I would say very light workload. Although there are 8 HWs, they are 10 MCQs each. I could skip Midterm exam because of this grading scheme. no attendance but there is iPRS, so i attended every lecture.

Before mid term the course is mostly about some phenomenon on earth, like tidal effect, eclipse and stuff.

After mid term it talks about universe.Say, the formation of stars, nebula, black hole, dark matter etc.

reviews.comment_content: I didn't select the Astro elective in the DSE and it still turned out fine. The contents get difficult near the end of the course, but you will surely get a blast if you are really into astronomy but didn't want to touch on too many in-depth physics terms and calculations.

reviews.comment_grading:
IPRS:5%,
Basically answering 1 online question at the end of each lecture in 2-3 minutes after the add drop-period. 1 mark for correct answers, 0.5 mark for wrong answers, 0 mark for no response. Only the top 80% is accounted for.

Midterm:38%
MC: 60, Long question MC: 40
Not too difficult, aside from the 3 long questions, most of them are quite straightforward, but beware of some minor mistakes and misconceptions.

Final exam: 57%
MC(Part A): 60, Long question MC(Section B): 40

Quite good already and better than my expectation.

Here is my result:
Midterm: 39/80 (mean: 38/80)
Final: 62/100 (mean: 56.x/100)
iPRS: 3.5/5
Final grade: B+

I thought I would get a B after the release of final result but eventually it was a B+. It is quite encouraging for me because I 've got a level 3 in HKDSE physics and I 've never studied astronomy as elective.

I had a friend who got mean score in both midterm and final (iPRS unknown but seemed not good) and he eventually got a B-.
To be objective, the grading cannot be regarded as "good" but at least not bad. MUCH better than the courses which gives out C+ for mean score.

reviews.author: TF
reviews.title: Informative but not very difficult
reviews.comment_content:
The lecture begins with the daily tangible astronomical stuff, such as the Sun, Moon and the movement of stars and planets observed from the Earth and briefly explain the impacts of their interactions (e.g. seasons, retrograde motions, tidal forces, etc.). This part includes simple calculation and theories only and the graphs and diagrams about motions of objects are relatively more important.

The second part is related to the properties and evolution of stars. The characteristics and structures of the Sun is introduced first. Then the professor will explain the procedures of nuclear reactions and its relationship with star evolution. Giants, dwarfs, nebulae and blackholes will be detailedly covered. This is the main part of the exam as well.

The third part is about the galaxy and universe. Although the concepts and theories are more intangible and complex, the professor will not go into details. Also, some of the arguments raised by cosmologists are not verified yet. Therefore, the focus will lie on the apparatus and methods of cosmological observations.

Personally I think the overall content is very clear and detailed. It is highly beneficial for students interested in astronomy. The only drawback is that some small concepts like microwaves and X-ray are recited frequently in different topics but not very well explained.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Chen's notes are easy to comprehend and it consists of plenty of graphs and animations to demonstrate the motions of star objects to assist students' studying. He is patient with students' questions as well.

For the assignments and exams, they are highly relevant to the examples and demonstrations taught in class and the Math computation questions are quite simple. The long questions only require brief explanations and the grading is lenient.

reviews.title: Interesting, Good amount of content. Ended up with B+.
reviews.comment_content:
Pre-midterm: Earth and Solar System-centered. Very manageable, especially with 2 sided cheat sheet for test.

Post-midterm: Quite a bit of content, though a 4 sided cheat sheet is allowed, will be fairly annoying to know the content. Each ppt has lot of info.

Most content is interesting, occasionally tedious to learn.
reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching from PPT. Professor is quite enthusiastic, but easy to zone out in class.

reviews.author: FeiFei
reviews.title: Be cautious if you expect a good grade
reviews.comment_content:
Detailed content could refer to others' reviews. There's not much changes.

The whole course gives a brief knowledge for astronomy & astrophysics, which is funny as a Common Core especially if you are a fan of it.

Midterm covers the first few chapters, which are related to more basic concepts of astronomy and classical physics.
Final covers all chapters mentioned in the syllabus, and will focus more on contents not tested in midterm.

If you have taken DSE Physics Elective E1, the contents (especially before midterm) should be easy for you. (At least for me)
reviews.comment_teaching:
The whole teaching process is mainly reading out the ppt .(Maybe it's the procedure for this kind of course?)

I can say it is still boring for lecture (with 30-50 slides every lecture), though some animations and videos are supplemented.

But Dr. Chen is a nice professor to answer your questions, and he will add a bit explanations for clarification.
He also gives more time for PRS so that you don't have to rush for answering.
reviews.comment_grading:
PRS(5%):
Count the best 80% only, excluding those during the add-drop period.
Done after finishing each lecture ppt, not necessarily the end of the whole lecture.
Midterm(30%):
One lecture as midterm time. 1 hour for midterm.
Final(65%):
3 hours for final exam.

My score:
Full PRS
Midterm: 90/100 (Mean: 78.7/100 SD: 16.6) (0.68 SD above mean)
Final: 156/180 (Mean: 130/180 SD: 28.6) (0.91 SD above mean)
Total: 88.33%

I was expecting for A-range for the result. And it turns out to be B+ only. SO where is the so-called good grade? It seems to be terrible for this result. OR am I that lucky to be the one under the cut-off? I don't know.

My good grade was sucked by black hole. My mind was blown like a supernova. My head shakes like a quasar. I just feel lost like in the spacetime. But all of these will be faded like the fate of the universe, and buried in the graveyard.

Anyway, just be cautious when you consider this course for good grades.

=======Edited at 8th June 2018 6:30pm======
After a day I posted this review, I noticed that my grade has been amended to A- (Note: I'm sure that I didn't see the grade wrong at first). Otherwise, you grade will be easily ruined by the high mean.

reviews.title: Covers basic fundamentals of astronomy and astrophysics for astronomy enthusiasts (like me)
reviews.comment_content:
I believe the content is manageable, taking it from someone who took the HKDSEs and not taking Astronomy as an elective (and also a year 1 student).
Note that the content before the Midterm (Ch.1-6) is not included in the Finals.
Anything before Midterms is very easy to understand, but be prepared to do quite a bit of self-study after that.

reviews.comment_teaching:
His style of teaching tends to make me doze off, even when I'm actually interested in the topic. But I do try to pay attention otherwise I have to go through all the thinking process when I do self-study with the powerpoint, which can take quite a while especially with topics after midterms.
But you can see that he's quite passionate about Astronomy (especially as he may overrun once in a while) and he's always happy to answer any questions.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is amazing in my opinion
Midterm: 38%
Final: 57%
PRS: 5%

For each PRS, just answering guarantees 0.5/1 marks, not answering is 0/1, so basically no worries for those who want those extra points.

Note that you can bring cheat sheet to the Midterm and Final. 2 pages in Midterm and 4 pages in Final. The Midterm and Final consist of MCs and about 2-3 problems.

----------------------

Mean: 69.96/100

----------------------
Final:
Mean: 82.17/120
SD: 19.45

reviews.comment_workload:
Very light workload, no homework is given (though he does upload 'homework' online, there is no need to hand it in and he'll post answers after some time)
He uploads the powerpoints which I think are enough for me to self-study, even when I doze off in lessons.
There's 1-2 PRS every end of a lecture based on the topic covered then.
As long as you review the content after each lecture, it should get you a good grade.

reviews.author: HJ613
reviews.comment_content: Interesting content if you are interested in learning about the basic fundamental knowledge of the universe. During the beginning of the semester it's pretty easy but toward the end of the semester the content gets lengthy and there's a lot to study for the finals.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor seems really interested in what he teaches, but he doesn't have the most exciting voice that draws students in, so if you don't actively pay attention you will find your attention drifting during class.
reviews.comment_grading: The mean tends to be really high, and the SD is super big. It doesn't have the best grading, but I got an average score for the mid-term but did well on the finals and it was enough to make up for my mid-term. The final counts more toward the grade than the midterm.
reviews.comment_workload: He does give out optional extra questions, you could do them if you wanted to make sure you understood the lectures properly, but other than that there is really not much to do except for the iPRS questions at the end of each lecture.

reviews.author: ad_inf1nitum
reviews.title: A stellar introduction to the macrocosm of astrophysics and astronomy.
reviews.comment_content:
The content of this class is derived from a textbook which is available for purchase at the bookstore. However, it is not necessary to purchase this book as all the information you need is provided by the instructor on the lecture slides.

The course will introduce the student to the nature of the cosmos through a thorough and satisfying scope, which includes basic astronomy (moon phases, solstices, equinoxes, celestial sphere), basic physics (Kepler, Newton, tides, EM waves, etc.) and then combines the two to progress towards the analyses of stars, galaxies, and the universe.

It is important to note that attendance is "required" in the sense that at the end of each lecture, there will be a PRS question, which WILL count towards your final grade, albeit only 5%.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Sou is an engaging and interesting lecturer and class rarely gets boring. There is engagement with the students and the content is well presented. He is also open to any questions asked during or after the lecture, which has helped the atmosphere of the class and understanding of the students.
reviews.comment_grading:
PRS (1 per lecture): 5%
Midterm (1): 38%
Final (1): 57%
reviews.comment_workload:
Since there are no quizzes throughout the course, mastery of the content is heavily reliant on self-study. Be sure to take time to look over the lecture notes in order to be ready for the exams.

Practise problems are also provided. It is not expected of the student to complete them, but they will help identify weak points in one's understanding.

A double-sided A4 typed/handwritten cheat sheet is allowed for the midterm. Make full use of this.

(At the time of writing the finals have not yet taken place. Review will be edited in due time.)

reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Tam's English is understandable. He wants us to get interested in this subject by watching movies. He speaks in a relatively flat and slow tone.
He would regularly ask students whether we catch up his points, and quite willing to answer students' inquiries.
reviews.comment_grading:
I did not remember the exact grading.
But attending movie sections and completing the iPRS is definitely a way to get high scores

No mid-term exam, final exam all multiple choices and true or false.

I attended 8-9 movies sections (out of 11) and got around 60% correct  (160/265) in my final exam (around the mean)

My final grade is B, not bad

No assignments.
Bear in mind that there are regular movie sections that count towards 30 % of your final grade so you are highly encouraged to attend all of them.

reviews.author: kenkong7058
reviews.comment_content: First few lecture are about seasons, the Moon, and observing stars. Then it's about stars, galaxies and the universe. Nothing about planet though. There's also some physics in between, like Newtons' law and nuclear fusion, but you only need to remember them.
reviews.comment_teaching: It's a bit nicer than PowerPoint-reading, but not a lot
reviews.comment_grading:
1. Final (55%) MCs, T/Fs(Textbook content and an artice about exoplanet)

Two A4 cheat sheets are allowed, MCs are not particularly difficult, provided you sqeezed everything them with font size 8. Marks will be deducted if you get the T/F wrong. There's very few calculations, I don't think I had used my calculator

2. PRS (30%) Answering questions with PRS in lectures

Questions are usually about the same lecture, calculations required sometimes, some are a bit tricky. Best 80% is counted

Activity/Movie(15%)
There's 10, 3 mark each, you'll need to sit through 5 for full mark. 1 mark for every extra

222/265 in final, feels like 60-70% for PRS, went to 5/6 movie, got A-
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is close to none, only need to attend the documentaries after class and prepare cheat sheets for final. I spend half a week for the cheat sheets

reviews.author: Lemonwong
reviews.title: No physic at all in final
reviews.comment_content:
The course is composed of three part:
1.Final (50%)
2.Movie(35%) (Yes, you need to watch movie besides the lecture time)
3.IPRS(15%)
The content is generally interesting. If you are interested in physics, you will find it not difficult to comprehend the concept. But it's actually fine that you don't understand the content because you just need to memorise everything in the final to get a high mark.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The teaching is sometimes interesting but my instructor said that was his last year of teaching.
You need to do IPRS two to three times which spread evenly during the class. Most of the questions are tricky and you need to pay attention not to fall into traps.
reviews.comment_grading:
It is absolutely ridiculous that the final is totally not about physics, it's a course of memorising all the content (mostly the latter part of the syllabus) if you want to get a good grade, not to mention marks will be deducted if you answered incorrectly.
There will be 3 parts of the final
A. MC
B.True or False
C. Passage reading (YES, it's basically a Lang course)
It is not as it seems as a good grade course. All the candidates were shocked that not a single question required calculator so you don't need to worry about forgetting to bring it. But for reference, the mean was about 50% and i got a B- with a mark slightly higher than mean.
reviews.comment_workload: There will be 10 movies in total. You need to watch 5 of them to get 15marks for the movies. The movie watched afterwards will be counted one bonus mark for each, so you can get at maximum 5 bonus marks. Though each movie is about 2 to 3 hours long and you need to go to lecture and watch them in the time assigned by the instructor, which mostly in your leisure time.

reviews.author: phcheungac
reviews.title: never reg this course if no science background
reviews.comment_content: It is quite difficult as a common core course, especially for the students without or lack of science background. Even you have studied Physics in HKDSE does not mean you know what happened. People without the real interest in Astronomy and Aerospace should never reg this course.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor is passionate to teach with different ways of examples and elaborations, but he is just too boring and you will find it difficult to summarize his teaching. You will find many students fall asleep in his lessons because you will lose the focus with his voice. The ppt covers a lot but you are not easy to sort out the useful materials for your exams.
reviews.comment_grading: Prof gave a very good grade generally, but at least you need to catch up with the knowledge. If you got midterm or final score around the mean, the grade must be B-range if you do not below mean 1 SD or more in either one exam. If you are below mean 1 SD or more in both exam, you may still get a C, which is quite kind for the professor. Also, there is a rumor that the prof will give generally more A-range comparing other S&T common core courses.
reviews.comment_workload: No homework or workload, only need to take PRS for every lecture. However, you have to do revision regularly, maybe once or twice a week. Otherwise you probably cannot handle the stuff well before the exam. The reading material and ppt are too many for a student to prepare and revise within a week, so you better prepare well for every week.

reviews.author: wasd0109
reviews.title: Good grade and fun course.

The starting part with celestial etc. took me sometime to understand but overall it's not really hard.
I have studied Phys 1112 but most of the content are irrelevant to 1112 and so no need to worry about someone massacring.

Both mt and final allow cheat sheets so there is no need to recite formula. However, questions could be tricky and need you to understand what the questions is actually asking and what you are doing.

I am 1 sd above mean and made some big big mistakes in final leading to 2 long questions being scoreless but still hit the mean.
End up to be B+.
reviews.comment_workload: Making your own cheat sheet is the most time consuming part. Make your own one and make sure that you understand what you are typing.

reviews.author: Alpha703
reviews.title: Good course in every aspect
reviews.comment_content:
Before mid-term, some general concepts about the universe, the 'sky' we observe and some basic astrophysics are covered. Having studied DSE Physics E1(Astronomy elective) will give you a little advantage before midterm, but it's easy for others to catch up.
Summary of topics included:
Key terms in astronomy, Look-Back Time, Use of scales in astronomy, Earth's orbit and rotation, Constellation, Celestial sphere, Seasons, Tropicals, Moon phases, Eclipses, Retrograde motion, Astronomy and ancient cultures, History and development of astronomical models, Ptolemaic/Heliocentric/Kepler model, Kepler's laws, Galilean Principle of Relativity, Newton's laws, Angular momentum, Thermal energy, Tides and Tidal forces, EM waves, Spectrums, Stefan-Boltzmann’s law, Wien’s law, Doppler effect, Telescopes

After mid-term, important concepts of modern cosmology are introduced.
Summary of topics included:
Sun(Structure, hydrostatic equilibrium, nuclear reactions, solar activities), Brightness(Luminosity and apparent brightness, relation with distance, distance modulus, relation with temperature, Spectral types), Binary star systems, HR Diagram(Luminosity class, main sequence stars, dwarfs, giants), Star clusters(Classification, evolution), Stellar Birth(Nebulae, process of creation of stars, limit of star masses), Stellar Death(Aging of stars, helium flash, planetary nebula, supernova explosion), White dwarfs(Formation, accretion disks, nova), Supernova(Type I and II), Neutron star(Formation, pulsars), Black Hole(Nature, Structure, Schwarzschild radius, Tidal forces, Gravitational effects), Galaxy(Types, Structures, Galactic recycling, history, collisions, galactic center), Spectroscopic parallax, Variable stars, Hubble’s Law, Cosmological Principle, Active galaxies(Quasars, Radio galaxies, structures, power sources), Dark matter(Possible composition, existence), Big Bang Model, Critical Density, Dark Energy, Fate of Universe
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Sou clearly shows his passion on teaching. His English is clear and can explain/introduce new physics/cosmology concepts to us in an organized way. It can be observed that he prepared a lot for the course as well, as he can discuss new or hotly debating issues/concepts in astronomy without much hesitation. The only thing to criticize(which doesn't affect my A ranking on teaching) is that his lecture notes are not tidy enough.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading Scheme:
5% PRS (1 per lesson, 1 mark per correct answer, 0.5 mark per wrong answer, 0 mark for no answer, 80% best marks counted - you get full mark in this part if answered >80% questions correctly)
38% Mid-term exam
57% Final exam
In my opinion, the grading is wonderful.
Mid-term: 96/100(Mean 74.44, SD 13.38 +1.61SD)
Final: 76.5/100(Mean 64.18 SD 15.64 +0.79SD)
PRS: 15/15(Mean 11.9)
Total 87.21/100 --> A
Btw, I know some friends who get slightly below mean in both exams but still got B-, and some get mean in mid-term, slight above mean in final, got B+. Very generous grading.
I must also declare that I didn't study DSE Physics E1(Astronomy elective), but the outcome is still good.
reviews.comment_workload:
Light workload.
Attendance: As with all PRS attendances you can ask your friend to help you or just attend the lesson at the last 15 minutes of it). Skipping lessons is not recommended after mid-term
Homework: Non-compulsory. For your own practice. Do them if you have time.
Exam: Cheatsheet (nearly) means everything.
-Mid-term: 1 A4 two-sided cheatsheet allowed. Not much to say. Questions are quite straightforward, so cheatsheet is everything. Note that this amount of cheatsheet is only barely enough to fit everything taught before mid-term into it.
-Final exam: 2 A4 two-sided cheatsheet allowed. More than enough for me. Do note that some MCs are significantly more tricky than mid-term, and some can only be answered by geniue astronomy enthusiasts(who deserves an A+ in this course). LQs are not hard, but spend some time to read the questions as they actually explicitly implies what you should do to get the answers. Make sure to use the correct units.

reviews.author: apple pie
reviews.comment_content:
Course Outline
A Modern View of the Universe
Discovering the Universe for Yourself
The Science of Astronomy
Making Sense of the Universe: Understanding Motion, Energy, and Gravity
Light and Matter: Reading messages from the Cosmos;Telescopes: Portals of Discovery
Our Star
Surveying the Stars
Star Birth and Star Stuff
The Bizarre Stellar Graveyard
Our Galaxy
Galaxies and the Foundation of Modern Cosmology;
Galaxy Evolution
The Birth of the Universe;Dark Matter, Dark Energy, and the Fate of the Universe
reviews.comment_teaching: It is quite boring when the lecturer just tell you the things which are already mentioned on the lecture note. But the lecturer is kindly answer your question.
reviews.comment_grading:
5% PRS
38% Midterm
57% Final
The grading is fair.
Midterm: mean:74.5 SD:13
Final: mean:64.2 SD:15.6
I got the mean in my midterm and my final above 0.5 SD. I got an B+
reviews.comment_workload:
Only PRS
If you do not have PHY E1 before, I do not recommend you to take this course since the others is already having a good background and understanding on the topic and you will feel extremely hard to catch up the content if you miss any lessons.

reviews.author: cywongbh
reviews.title: Basic Astronomy
reviews.comment_content:
Mostly taught is basic astronomy, but with some dark matter and energy,which are not included in exam.

Very easy to astronomy enthusiast and those who are with strong physics background. But still need some effort if you have no idea with astronomy.
reviews.comment_teaching: Nearly read the PPT directly. But sometimes the things are not on the notes, so you still need to listen carefully.
reviews.comment_grading:
Easy to get A range if you have gone through notes.

I am around no. 9-13 sth in 200 students but still got A. So you can see there should be many students who get A range
reviews.comment_workload:
Only midterm and final. Cheat sheet is allowed.

The paper is very easy to do and should be with enough time, so no need to do it in a rush. Try to read the question carefully.

reviews.author: WYKEI
reviews.title: good grade
reviews.comment_content: Introduction to our Universe; observation in astronomy; origin of modern astronomy.  Newton's law of motions; gravity; light, atoms and telescope. The Sun; stellar formation and evolution; white dwarfs, neutron stars and black holes. The Milky way Galaxy; Normal galaxies, active galaxies and supermassive black holes. Foundation of modern cosmology; dark matter, dark energy and the fate of the Universe; the beginning of time.
reviews.comment_teaching: If you are not interested in astronomy, it will be quite boring. Although the instructor tried to use a different way to express the concepts, it made it worse. There was a lot of videos, news and photos, some of them was very interesting. They will provide tutorial sessions before the exam, you may ask them questions or seek for help.
reviews.comment_grading:
You need to take iPRS in every lesson which will be counted in the total score. You will get a lower marks if you choose the wrong answer. There is 10-12 movies[ not during the lecture] , you need to watch at least 5 of them, extra marks will be given if you watch more.
The grading was quite good, I got 65/95 [mean=61] in the mid-term and 101/175[mean=114] in the final but I still got B in this course.
reviews.comment_workload:
No assignment but need to take iPRS and watch the videos.
For the rules of iPRS:
Full marks for correct answers, half marks for incorrect answers, 0 marks for no answers. The best 80% of each student will be counted for the total marks for PRS.
Marks will not be counted during the add-drop period. As there was only MC and T/F questions, workload  will not be very heavy.
In the exam, use of ONE summary sheet (A4-sized, can be printed/written on both sides) will be allowed.
Here is the weighting:
PRS_Total 10.0%
Midterm         30.0%
Movie         15.0%
Final Exam 45.0%
Total 100%

reviews.author: PeanutBoy
reviews.comment_content:
Chapters before midterm are easier, mostly included in the HKDSE physics astronomy module. More complex content swarms in after midterm.

Constellation, seasons, phases of moon, eclipses, different astronomy models and philosophies, tides, light (luminosity, doppler's effect etc.),  telescopes, structure, birth, and death of stars, planets, galaxies and black holes, stellar parallax, detection methods, big bang model, inflation theory, dark matter, dark energy etc.

The content sounded really fascinating to me. It is a great choice if you wish to learn more about astronomy.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching is generally alright. I can feel that Dr. Tam does care about his teaching. He and his TAs are very willing to answer students' questions after class. But at times it can be tiring to listen to Dr. Tam's accent and presentation, especially when you had a long day of class. Another drawback is that his powerpoints are often not concise enough. For me, I removed slides that are not necessary and regrouped the content into fewer slides for later use.
reviews.comment_grading:
10% - PRS
15% - Movie sessions
(5 compulsory sessions for the first 10%, then attending an extra one grant another 1%. Just be present there for an hour and then you gain a bonus 1%. Simple.)
30% - Midterm
45% - Final

Although the grading is not as good as PHYS1003, but it's still ok. I got a B+ for reaching >80%.
reviews.comment_workload: In my opinion, the real workload only lies on creating cheat sheets for midterm and final. To do or not to do the PRS and extra movie sessions are entirely up to you.

reviews.author: pdf
reviews.title: Cheatsheet is everything
reviews.comment_content: Introductory course for astronomy so you are expected to learn all the stuff in the universe ranging from planets to galaxy clusters to special relativity and blackholes lol If you are interested in stuff like that you will find it very easy to understand. There are lots of extra and undated knowledge shared by professor such as gravity wave which is very interesting in my opinion. Some calculations are required but really simple....
reviews.comment_teaching: Easy to follow and up-to-date...although sometimes it's a bit boring (maybe because of prof's voice? idk) And prof are willing to ans your questions which is really nice..there are also TAs who are extremely helpful...
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm final above 1SD
Got an A finally
Basically MCs...if you have prepared well your cheatsheet then there shouldn't be much problem...
reviews.comment_workload: No workload

reviews.author: Byiu
reviews.comment_content:
主要講我地係地球見到既一d關於universe既現象既成因, 同埋而家見到呢個universe係點樣演變出黎, e.g star light and atoms, stars (binary, formation, evolution, death), neutron stars and black holes, normal galaxies, peculiar galaxies.
最後會講下少少而家天文物理學家關心既課題, 即係cosmology, e.g dark matter and dark energy
reviews.comment_teaching: 講書都幾悶下, 不過幾清楚
reviews.comment_grading:
midterm~38%
final~57%
prs~5%

mean= B- ~ B

雖然呢科教既野唔難, 不過最好有興趣先好讀. 因為佢係一科好注重背野既physics, 係powerpoint會發現大部份都係文字, midterm同final都幾多野背, 所以exam前唔好太過輕視呢科. 如果冇興趣, 相信會背得幾辛苦下
reviews.comment_workload: 冇workload可言, 最多係果5%prs, assignment唔計分, exam前花多少少時間溫書就ok

reviews.author: Omar
reviews.comment_content: The content of this course is basically all the cahpters in the book named "Cosmic Perspective" and it is quite long. Starting with "looking at the sky" up to "dark energy and inflation theory" the content will be harder as you move on during the semester.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor is really nice and is doing his best to explain difficult concepts to non-physics students. He is willing to answer questions after the lectures. To me, his english is better than "just good", but it is the pace and the tone of his speaking that actually makes me fall asleep. So, professor is really good at teaching.
reviews.comment_grading:
There are 4 things to be taken into account for the final grades:
PRS >>> 10%
Movie attendance >>> 15%
Midterm >>> 30%
Final exam >>> 45%
And you can get bonus points by attending extra movies. Also you should attend the lectures to do the PRS, since they give 0.5 for wrong answers and 1 for correct answers.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is really light. I mean, you just have to go to the lectures, the movies and practice for the exams which are MCs. Because the content is litlle longer, you should start revision long before the study breaks.

reviews.author: AIU
reviews.comment_content:
The content was more or less simple as it was detailedly explain in the lecture notes.

(You can bring cheat sheet to exams)

Textbook is recommended if you have difficulties in understanding the concepts.
(can be borrowed in library, not a reserve book)
reviews.comment_teaching: Very boring tone, read directly from Powerpoint slide
reviews.comment_grading:
So-so
As long as you get above mean for around 0.5 SD for mid term and final, you are quite sure to get a B or above, more than 1.5 SD can almost guaranteer an A.
reviews.comment_workload:
No homework
PRS questions greatly related to the class material.

reviews.author: ChuaWanZhen
reviews.title: PHYS 1002 - Can have a brief understanding about the outer space
reviews.comment_content: This course introduces students to origin of modern astronomy, gravity, light and telescope, star light and atoms, stars (binary, formation, evolution, death), neutron stars and black holes, normal galaxies, peculiar galaxies, cosmology, the solar system, life on other world. The content before midterm is relatively easier which focus more on the moon, the four seasons on earth and the position of stars at the night sky
reviews.comment_teaching: Mr Sou is a responsible professor. He is willing to answer any questions from students. He encourages us to think and ask more as he likes to interact and exchange ideas with students.
reviews.comment_grading: The grade of this course is quite good. Professor Sou is willing to give 20 percent of As. 57 percent final, 38 percent midterm and 5 percent of PRS. You will get 1 mark for each correct answer, 0.5 mark for a wrong answer and 0 for no answer. There will be 1-2 PRS questions during each lecture. He will take 80 percent of your best marks for the PRS. The mean for the midterm will be relatively high which is 77 and 68 for the final
reviews.comment_workload: No homework and assignment. Midterm consists of 15 MCQs (60 marks) and 40 marks of long questions. Final consists of 40 MCQs (80 marks) and 20 marks of long questions. A cheat sheet is allowed for midterm and two are allowed for the final

reviews.author: YL
reviews.comment_content:
mid term前ok，同中學學既野差唔多，但mid term後就難到痴左線。
大家reg前要三思，唔好以為中學讀過phys E1就carry到個course，會中伏。
reviews.comment_teaching: 英文易明，教得好有heart，難得一見既好老師。
reviews.comment_grading:
唔識判斷既。
利申mid term mean，final完全睇唔明，早走一個鐘。最終C左。
reviews.comment_workload: 0 workload，得PRS。

reviews.author: chchanca+++vcv
reviews.title: A good grade course
reviews.comment_content: Topics before midterm are generally easy. You should be able to excel in the midterm if you have a good foundation in DSE Maths and Physics, even you may not have studied  the astronomy elective in DSE Physics before. However, the real journey to astronomy starts after midterm. The main focus is the universe structure, eg how stars form and how stars die, and dark energy about an acceleratingly expanding universe. Since the course is only an introduction, as its name suggests, the topics are not too hard if you are willing to work hard.
reviews.comment_teaching: Despite of the difficulty of topics, and his English proficiency, Mr Sou is really enthusiastic about physics and he works really hard to make his presentation as clear as possible to students. Mr Sou is really respectable.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is generally good. For my performance, 78/100 in midterm (38% of course grade and 0.3 sd above mean), 84/100 in final (57% of course grade and 1.1 sd above mean), and 4.26/5 in PRS. An A- in the end which I really haven't expected.
reviews.comment_workload: Generally not huge workload. Since I have studied DSE Physics before, which is not a must to get good grades here, I didn't revise much for the midterm but my result is not too bad, still acceptable. And I revised the powerpoint notes several times for the final. My final result is good. I would say if you are willing to work hard, you can get good grade in the course regardless of your foundation.

reviews.author: grqm
reviews.comment_content:
基礎天文知識
對天文有興趣既話真係唔洗點讀

midterm前主要係dse phy 天文elective既野, e.g., celestial sphere, Kepler's laws
midterm後就教新野, 好似our star, star formation & evolution, our galaxy, galaxy formation & evolution, cosmology & big bang, dark matter & dark energy之類 好有趣

midterm同final既LQ好淺
cheat sheet冇乜用
唔洗點計數 concept同fact為主
MC會有2-3題難d 但係整體都係易
有讀過dse 天文elective可以唔洗溫midterm
reviews.comment_teaching:
一般
只係對住powerpoint讀
不過有時會講d課外野
reviews.comment_grading:
prs 5%
midterm 38%
final 57%

CC黎講算好grade 最重要係內容唔多同唔難(例如比較phys1003)

midterm above 1.5 sd
final above 1.6 sd => A+

其實midterm同final難度相若
唔知點解final個mean低好多
reviews.comment_workload:
如果本身對天文有興趣就冇乜workload
因為個course好多野都係天文常識
考試又出得唔難
最煩係prs

reviews.author: TCheung
reviews.comment_content: Basic concepts about astronomy, including stars, galaxies, dark matter, dark energy, etc..
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Tam has a really poor tone in comparison with other local professor, but still understandable.

He is willing to stay after the lectures and answer students' questions in Cantonese.
reviews.comment_grading:
Good grading. My midterm and final are only around the median, finally got B+.

Cheat sheets are allowed in both the midterm and final, but like other courses, don't expect them to be very useful.

Midterm  30%
Final  50%
PRS  10%
Movie  10%
reviews.comment_workload:
Light workload.

No homework is required. Students only have to attend several movie watching session to gain 10% of the total marks. (actually documentary instead of movie...)

reviews.author: SVM
reviews.title: Good Course. Recommended!
reviews.comment_content: Basic content related to astronomy. Not too difficult, even for someone who's not done astronomy before. There is a textbook, but it's not really needed, the professor's slideshows are sufficient.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Sou has a voice well suited for lullabies, and generally 20 minutes into the lecture about 75% of the class is sleeping.
reviews.comment_grading: You are allowed cheat sheets for the mid term and final, which is a real life saver. Grading is good, overall.
reviews.comment_workload: Hardly any workload. However, if you have never studied astronomy before, it is highly recommended that you study regularly. Since I had already studied astronomy before, I didn't have to do that.

reviews.author: navI
reviews.comment_content: Prof. Tam like to mess up students' mind by introducing abstract ideas like the meaning of terms in Einstein's field equation. After all, those complex ideas will not be tested in exams. Though the content is somehow difficult to understand, it will be interesting from the perspective of a astronomy lover.
reviews.comment_teaching: Overall, Prof. Tam is a responsible lecturer. However, I will not say he is a perfect lecturer since his tone and way of speaking  was not able to catch my attention all the time.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading of the course is not bad at all, just as what I mentioned in "workload". Even though you have a poor midterm result, your excellence in the final can chase up after all. For me, my final above 1.5 SD and midterm above 0.97 SD. I turned out got an A.
reviews.comment_workload: I can say it got  no daily workload at all. You only have to make good exams, regular participation in class and movie sections, you can all what you should have.

reviews.author: O
reviews.comment_content:
It is quite easy and fun if you love Astronomy.
The course before midterm mainly give you a simple knowledge for astrophysics and there are quite few equations.
However, after midterm, the content will be more difficult and more equations will be included. But it is still manageable since the exam has only short questions and MC and you really dont need to know the details.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof Chan is quite funny professor. He used funny expressions and demonstration. There are also some video for you to watch in the lessons.
reviews.comment_grading:
The cheatsheets are allowed in both test and exam. You can put the ppts as much as you can do and they will definitely help you a lot in exams since there are only MC and short questions.
Got B+ in the end because not enough time for cheatsheet in midterm lol
reviews.comment_workload:
No work is needed. Only there are PRS in the lecture you need to take to count maybe 5% marks.
Sometimes the questions can be quite confusing but even you got wrong ans, half marks will give to you.

reviews.author: 雪耳
reviews.title: 淺談PHYS 1002
reviews.comment_content: 內容淺白，可以帶cheat sheet，記熟公式就可以應付自如。考試會考細微細眼位，例如地球和太陽距離，要盡用cheat sheet 空間，把lecture notes 的東西寫曬落去。
reviews.comment_teaching: 上課時有動畫看，生動有趣，教授有心教，直得上堂。
reviews.comment_grading:
Absolute grading
Total Score = 2% * PRS + 60% * Final Exam Score + 38% * Max[ midterm exam score, final exam score ]

[90, 100] : A+
[80, 90): A
[70, 80): A-
[65, 70): B+
[60, 65): B
[55, 60): B-
[45, 55): C+
[40, 45): C
[35, 40): C-
[25, 35): D
[0, 25): F
reviews.comment_workload: 課堂上有PRS，冇功課。

reviews.author: N1ck
reviews.title: DSE無讀Astronomy geh衝 jo 入嚟
reviews.comment_content:
More calculations for mid-term, more facts and theories for finals.
A large portion of the course (especially the mid-term) repeats the DSE physics elective one astronomy.
For someone who has not taken elective one, the course is a little bit heavy (quite a lot to learn)
Overall, tension but fun and achievable.

Course Outline

PART I: Developing Perspective

Chapter 1

A Modern View of the Universe

Chapter 2

Discovering the Universe for Yourself

Chapter 3

The Science of Astronomy

PART II: Key Concepts for Astronomy

Chapter 4

Making Sense of the Universe: Understanding Motion, Energy,  and Gravity

Chapter 5-6

Light and Matter: Reading messages from the Cosmos;

Telescopes: Portals of Discovery

PART III: Stars

Chapter 14

Our Star

Chapter 15

Surveying the Stars

Chapter 16-17

Star Birth and Star Stuff

Chapter 18

The Bizarre Stellar Graveyard

PART IV: Galaxies and Beyond

Chapter 19

Our Galaxy

Chapter 20-21

Galaxies and the Foundation of Modern Cosmology;

Galaxy Evolution

Chapter 22-23

The Birth of the Universe;

Dark Matter, Dark Energy, and the Fate of the Universe
reviews.comment_teaching:
The powerpoint is clean and clear. You can find all the key points there. It is good to read it for revision.
Professor Sou is able to provide further explanations, so it is good to attend his lessons. However, his boring tone never fails to put me to sleep.
reviews.comment_grading:
Mid-term 84/100
Final exam 97/100
Grade A+
reviews.comment_workload:
No homework needed to hand in. Only iPRS every lesson, a mid-term and a final.
The pressure was quite big as everyone seems to be so good at it. Even though the materials were just taught in the lessons, many already can answer the questions correctly.

reviews.author: Jerry sh
reviews.comment_content:
PART I: Developing Perspective

Chapter 1 A Modern View of the Universe
Chapter 2 Discovering the Universe for Yourself
Chapter 3 The Science of Astronomy

reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. CHEN has a good understanding of the knowledge, so if you ask some deeper question, he can always give reasonable and high-quality explanation.

Prof. is patient at the first half, and will leave quite some time for us to ask questions, but in this second half the prof. is trying to speed up the teaching process and sometimes may also ignore my e-mail to ask some question...
reviews.comment_grading: I guess the grading is fair. Only 3 is higher than me in midterm among 200 students. But I didn't perform well in the final (20 points lower than high). And I finally got A, which is acceptable.
reviews.comment_workload:
No compulsory homework. But PRS in each course.

Maybe reviewing the lecture notes before exam is a bit tough, because this course really cover a wide range of knowledge.

reviews.author: desmondfanclub
reviews.comment_content: Introductory class on stars, galaxies, black hole and a bit of cosmology. For midterm and final you are allowed to bring 2 pages and four pages of cheat sheet, respectively. It was an okay class. After the midterm, it got a lot more difficult as they try to cram in more topics.
reviews.comment_teaching: Didn't attend lectures especially after the first three weeks. But on those lectures that I did attend, the professor mostly read out of the PowerPoint.
reviews.comment_grading:
1. iPRS (1 per lecture)
2. Mid-term
3. Final exam

There's quite a lot of calculations in the exams and not a lot of theory imo. IPRS counts to 5% of your final grade, I missed nearly half of it and those that I actually did, I got wrong.

midterm: 78/100
final:106/125
final grade: A
reviews.comment_workload: No assignments, only the two exams + hrs

reviews.author: anonymoususer
reviews.title: Not beginner friendly but good grade
reviews.comment_content: I didn't take astronomy in secondary school. Though I have got good grade in DSE physics, I still found the contents in the course (especially those before the midterm) difficult to understand. I guess it would take a lot of time for a beginner like me to read through the powerpoint and understand the contents.
reviews.comment_teaching: Fair. Dr. Chen reads the powerpoint and tries to explain the concepts clearly, does try to make jokes during the lecture.
reviews.comment_grading:
Good. Final grade A-.
For the midterm, I started reading it a day before the exam and I only got mean.
For the final, I also started reading it one day before, made a good cheatsheet, and got 1sd above mean.
Given the efforts I paid throughout the semester, I think the grade is very good.
reviews.comment_workload:
It depends on your expected grade. If you expected to get an A-, you just have to be in the lectures and take the iprs (need not understand the contents). Make a good cheatsheet (includes literally ALL the things in the ppt) a day before and attend the exams.
The workload is quite light if you don't aim high.

reviews.author: MIYANO
reviews.title: Materials in lecture notes are difficult, but exams are reasonable
reviews.comment_content: This course was recommended by my friend before, and she said it was interesting. Actually, the part before midterm is quite interesting especially constellation, which is romantic. However, content after midterm is difficult and coherent and not very interesting. Things taught are mostly assumptions and are not directly proved. So it could be difficult to believe and accept, at least for me.
reviews.comment_teaching: Is good. He would provide Chinese meanings for some terms, making it easier to understand. And he will explain the prs before/at the same time we do it, and prs are usually easy.
reviews.comment_grading:
Good.
Midterm(30%) 100/100 mean: 67.3 sd: 16.9
Final(65%) 166/180 mean: 123 sd: 31 max: 176
Prs(5%) full
94.94%——>A+
reviews.comment_workload: No workload except before exams......Going through all the ppts and making cheat sheet made me crazy.... Sample paper is really important, since same questions will appear in the exams. Questions asked in the exams are reasonable and even some are common sense. So it is still a good course.

good grading.

reviews.comment_workload: almost no workload. there is homework but no submission is required.

reviews.author: Leon H
reviews.comment_content: Basic Astrophysics and Astronomy
reviews.comment_teaching: The lectures are a little boring. The professor just simply read out all the scripts in the slides, so it doesn't matter if you pay attention to him. However, he answered questions raised by student patiently, and made abstract concepts easy to understand. I think he's a good professor if you really want to learn something in the course.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm: 89/100  (Mean: 79, SD:15)
Final: 165/180  (Mean: 131, SD: 28)

Final Grade: 91.3 -> A
reviews.comment_workload: Not much workload. Making cheatsheet cost plenty of time, but only before the exams. 5% PRS every lecture, remember to attend if you don't want to lose them.

reviews.author: sjjtchen
reviews.title: take it if interested
reviews.comment_content:
PART I: Developing Perspective
Chapter 1A Modern View of the Universe
Chapter 2Discovering the Universe for Yourself
Chapter 3The Science of Astronomy
